article:
The 'Dewey Decimal Classification' (DDC), or 'Dewey Decimal System', is a
proprietary library classification system created by Melvil Dewey in
1876. It has been revised and expanded through 23 major editions, the
latest issued in 2011. [http://www.oclc.org/dewey/versions/default.htm DDC
23 Print Edition] Dewey was responsible for all revisions until his death
in 1931. A designation number, such as Dewey 16 for the 16th edition, is given
for each revision.

A library assigns a DDC number that unambiguously locates a particular volume to
within a short length of shelving which makes it easy to find any particular
book and return it to its proper place on the library shelves. Consider as
an example a book on the network protocol IPv6. It will be located at 004.62,
after general networking books at 004.6. The shelf location is thus
defined. The system is used in 200,000 libraries in at least 135
countries. {{cite web
| url =http://www.oclc.org/dewey/default.htm title =Dewey Services year =2009
| publisher=Online Computer Library Center accessdate =November 4, 2009 quote
| =Offers library users familiarity and consistency of a time-honored
| classification system used in 200,000 libraries worldwid
